Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Yo crawler people


Could possibly have something to do with the SNI implem=
entation in JDK7.


https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7615645/ssl-handsha=
ke-alert-unrecognized-name-error-since-upgrade-to-java-1-7-0


SNI is used =
by the webserver to host different certificates on the same port so you do =
not need one ip for each encrypted domain.

In java SNI is supported in a h=
acky manner by looking at the raw TLS stream received from the cilent befor=
e doing the handshake.

The point of this is to get the domain name from th=
e client before doing the handshake with the correct certificate for the do=
main the client is requesting.

This to accommodate more encrypted certific=
ates/domains on the same TLS port.


BTW: SNI is what (open)wayback needs t=
o support https in proxy mode... though SNI support is not supported server=
 side even in JDK8.

There is however a snippet of code which works in the =
hacky manner described. Maye JDK9 has finally got SNI server side support, =
haven't check yet.


If I find some time I could probably check to see if S=
NI is the problem for your domain.


Another good reason to used jdk8 is al=
so that jdk7 only supported 2048 bit certificates while jdk8 supports 4096 =
bit certificates which are become more common.


Best

Nicholas


_________=
_______________________

So it seems to be an SSL issue. I trie=
d adding "-Djsse.enableSNIExtension=3Dfalse" to my JAVA_OPTS but this doesn=
't work either. Does anyone has an idea how to solve this issue? I see it w=
ith OpenJDK8 as well as with Oracle Java 8 (3.3.0 current snapshop).

Cheer=
s,
David

<div id=3D"divtagdefaultwrapper" style=
=3D"font-size:12pt;color:#000000;font-family:Calibri,Helvetica,sans-serif;"=
 dir=3D"ltr">
<p>Yo crawler people<br>
</p>
<p><br>
</p>
<p>Could possibly =
have something to do with the SNI implementation in JDK7.</p>
<p><br>
</p>
=
<p><a href=3D"https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7615645/ssl-handshake-ale=
rt-unrecognized-name-error-since-upgrade-to-java-1-7-0" class=3D"OWAAutoLin=
k" id=3D"LPlnk640224" previewremoved=3D"true">https://stackoverflow.com/que=
stions/7615645/ssl-handshake-alert-unrecognized-name-error-since-upgrade-to=
-java-1-7-0</a></p>
<p><br>
</p>
<p>SNI is used by the webserver to host di=
fferent certificates on the same port so you do not need one ip for each en=
crypted domain.</p>
<p>In java SNI is supported in a hacky manner by lookin=
g at the raw TLS stream received from the cilent before doing the handshake=
.</p>
<p>The point of this is to get the domain name from the client before=
 doing the handshake with the correct certificate for the domain the client=
 is requesting.</p>
<p>This to accommodate more encrypted certificates/doma=
ins on the same TLS port.</p>
<p><br>
</p>
<p>BTW: SNI is what (open)waybac=
k needs to support https in proxy mode... though SNI support is not support=
ed server side even in JDK8.</p>
<p>There is however a snippet of code whic=
h works in the hacky manner described. Maye JDK9 has finally got SNI server=
 side support, haven't check yet.</p>
<p><br>
</p>
<p>If I find some time I=
 could probably check to see if SNI is the problem for your domain.</p>
<p>=
<br>
</p>
<p>Another good reason to used jdk8 is also that jdk7 only suppor=
ted 2048 bit certificates while jdk8 supports 4096 bit certificates which a=
re become more common.<br>
</p>
<p><br>
</p>
<p>Best</p>
<p>Nicholas</p>
<p=
><br>
</p>
</div>
